video.title: TEDTalks: Let Your Mind Wonder
video.synopsis: This collection of TED-Ed lessons features collaborations between animators and educators, exploring an array of scientific and philosophical topics.

episodes.synopsis: In the first of a series designed to catalyze curiosity, Chris Anderson shares his boyhood obsession with quirky questions without apparent answers.
episodes.title: Chris Anderson: Questions No One Knows the Answers to

episodes.synopsis: When you eat something loaded with sugar, your taste buds, your gut and your brain all take notice. Nicole Avena explains why moderation is important.
episodes.title: Nicole Avena: How Sugar Affects the Brain

episodes.synopsis: Adam Savage walks through two spectacular examples of scientific discoveries that came from simple, creative methods anyone could have followed.
episodes.title: Adam Savage: How Simple Ideas Lead to Scientific Discoveries

episodes.synopsis: Emma Bryce makes a compelling case for dining on bugs. You may feel icky about munching on insects, but they feed about 2 billion people each day.
episodes.title: Emma Bryce: Should We Eat Bugs?

episodes.synopsis: Fantasy constructed languages have the complexities of real languages: a high volume of words, grammar rules, and room for messiness and evolution.
episodes.title: John McWhorter: Are Elvish, Klingon, Dothraki and Na'vi Real Languages?

episodes.synopsis: Just how small are atoms? And what's inside them? The answers turn out to be astounding, even for those who think they know.
episodes.title: Jonathan Bergmann: Just How Small Is an Atom?

episodes.synopsis: "Yaawwn." Did just reading the word make you feel like yawning? Claudia Aguirre visits the intriguing theories that might explain contagious yawning.
episodes.title: Claudia Aguirre: Why Is Yawning Contagious?

episodes.synopsis: From gravity to the human genome, a stunning animation of John Lloyd's classic TEDTalk explains what really matters in the world is impossible to see.
episodes.title: John Lloyd: What's Invisible? More than You Think

episodes.synopsis: Although a third of the population suffers from motion sickness, scientists aren't sure what causes the seemingly simple problem without a cure.
episodes.title: Rose Eveleth: The Mystery of Motion Sickness

episodes.synopsis: What traits unite many of literature's most interesting heroes? Matthew Winkler takes us through the crucial events that make or break a hero.
episodes.title: Matthew Winkler: What Makes a Hero?

episodes.synopsis: Anita Collins explains the fireworks that go off in musicians’ brains when they play, and examines long-term positive effects of this mental workout.
episodes.title: Anita Collins: How Playing an Instrument Benefits Your Brain

episodes.synopsis: Explore the concept of the "infinity of infinities" and how it led mathematicians to conclude that math itself contains unanswerable questions.
episodes.title: Dennis Wildfogel: How Big Is Infinity?

episodes.synopsis: Alex Gendler details the causes of towering tsunamis and explains how scientists are seeking to reduce their destructiveness in the future.
episodes.title: Alex Gendler: How Tsunamis Work

episodes.synopsis: By dissecting a cockroach on stage, neuroscientist Greg Gage shows how brains receive and deliver electric impulses -- and how legs can respond.
episodes.title: Greg Gage: The Cockroach Beatbox

episodes.synopsis: Michael Molina digs up the science and the superstition about vampires, and talks about how we arrived at the popular image we know, love and fear.
episodes.title: Michael Molina: Vampires: Folklore, Fantasy and Fact

episodes.synopsis: If speaking in public makes you feel like you're fighting for your life, you're not alone. Mikael Cho advises how to deal with stage fright.
episodes.title: Mikael Cho: The Science of Stage Fright
